with [[Telford and Wrekin]] shown within |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1964 |type = Registered Charity |purpose = campaigns for wildlife and the environment; looks after nature reserves; encourages and educates about nature conservation |headquarters = 193 Abbey Foregate, [[Shrewsbury]] SY2 6AH |coords = 52.707 N, 2.7447 W {{coord|52.707|-2.7447|scale:5000|display=title}} |region_served = Shropshire, Telford & Wrekin |membership = ~10,000 |language = |main_organ = Trust Council |parent_organization = [[The Wildlife Trusts]] (partnership) |leader_title = Director |leader_name = Colin PrestonAnnual Review 2011 |num_staff = ~30 |num_volunteers = ~400 |budget = Â£1,098,853 ([[financial year|FY]] 2010-11) |website = [http://www.shropshirewildlifetrust.org.uk www.shropshirewildlifetrust.org.uk] }} The '''Shropshire Wildlife Trust''' is a [[wildlife]] [[trust (law)|trust]] covering the [[Ceremonial counties of England|geographic county]] of [[Shropshire]], [[England]]. ==Nature reserves== The trust cares for, or is associated with, 42 [[nature reserve]]s (plus its headquarters in Shrewsbury - see next section) in the county: {| style="border-collapse: collapse" width="60%" | width="50%" | North Shropshire | width="50%" | Central Shropshire |- | width="33%" valign="top" | *Birch Road Pond, near Ellesmere *Bwlytai Wood, near Oswestry *Craig Sychtyn, near Llynclys *Dolgoch Quarry, near Llynclys *Greenfields, near Whitchurch *Jones' Rough, near Llanymynech *[[Llanymynech]] Rocks *[[Llynclys]] Common *Melverley Farm, near Ash Magna *[[Prees Branch Canal Nature Reserve|Prees Branch Canal]] *[[Quarry Wood, Hinstock|Quarry Wood]] *Ruewood, near Wem *Steel Heath, near Whitchurch *Sweeney Fen, near Llynclys *The Plantation, near Ellesmere *Walkmill Marsh *[[Wem]] Moss *Wood Lane, near Wem | width="33%" valign="top" | *Betton Dingle *Brook Vessons *Earl's Hill, near Pontesbury *Holly Banks, near Melverley *Hope Valley *Granville, in Telford *[[Merrington Green]] *Monkmoor Pool, in Shrewsbury *Nipstone ([[Stiperstones]]) *Tasker Quarry *[[The Ercall]] *The Hollies South Shropshire *[[Bushmoor]] Coppice *Catherton Common *[[Chelmarsh]] *[[Clunton]] Coppice *Comley Quarry, near Church Stretton *Cramer Gutter *Harton Hollow *Knowle Wood *Lower Shortditch Turbary ([[Clun Forest]]) *Lurkenhope Wood *Rhos Fiddle *Whitcliffe Common, [[Ludford, Shropshire|Ludford]] |} [[File:ErcallHill.jpg|thumb|right|A former quarry at The Ercall]] Many of these sites are owned by the Trust - the most recent acquisition by the Trust is Catherton Common, in the [[Clee Hills]], which at 527 [[acre]]s is the largest Wildlife Trust nature reserve in the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] region. The Trust is currently fund-raising to purchase the [[leasehold]] of [[Pontesford]] Hill - it already owns the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]], along with neighbouring Earl's Hill. ==Headquarters== The Trust has its main offices and [[visitor centre]] at 193 Abbey Foregate near the centre of Shrewsbury - they occupy the former "Shrewsbury Quest" museum, on the corner of Abbey Foregate and Old Potts Way, opposite [[Shrewsbury Abbey|The Abbey]] church. The site encompasses a restored medieval building known as the Old Infirmary and a 1730s building called Queen Anne House, as well as gardens, including a [[herb garden]] established when the site was the Shrewsbury Quest, and a fruit tree garden. The centre and its gardens is open to the public (usually Monday â Saturday) and has a shop as well as [[Meeting|conference]] rooms available for hire. Many Trust-run events take place here, including children's events during the summer holidays. Every year the centre receives approximately 25,000 visitors. ==Local branches== The Trust currently has 10 local branches active in the county: *[[Bridgnorth]] *[[Clun]] and [[Bishop's Castle]] *[[Ellesmere, Shropshire|Ellesmere]] *[[Ludlow]] *[[Market Drayton]] *[[Newport, Shropshire|Newport]] *[[Oswestry]] **''Oswestry Hills Wildlife Watch'' *Shrewsbury Wildlife Survey Group *[[Church Stretton|Strettons]], The *[[Whitchurch, Shropshire|Whitchurch]] Additionally, in the Telford area the Trust has helped establish the "Telford and Wrekin Forest" initiative, and has "[[The Wrekin|Wrekin]] Forest Volunteers". ==Specialist groups== The county has a wide range of specialist groups, which are associated with the Shropshire Wildlife Trust, including: *[[Welsh Marches|Border]] [[Bryology|Bryologists]] *[[Butterfly]] Conservation West Midlands *Shropshire [[Amphibian]] and [[Reptile]] Group *Shropshire [[Badger]] Group *Shropshire [[Barn Owl]] Group *Shropshire [[Bat]] Group *Shropshire [[Botany|Botanical]] Society *Shropshire [[Fungus]] Group *Shropshire [[Invertebrate]] Group *Shropshire [[Mammal]] Group *Shropshire [[Moth]] Group *Shropshire [[Ornithology|Ornithological]] Society *Shropshire [[Raven]] Study Group ==Membership== As of 2011 the Shropshire Wildlife Trust's membership is around 10,000 individuals - the figure was just under 6,000 in the year 2000.Annual Review 2010 This equates to roughly 2.2%, or 1 in 50 Shropshire residents. Annual income from subscriptions has risen from Â£140,000 in 2000 to Â£250,000 in 2010.
